M.G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: COMPLAINT FOR BREACH OF THE COVENANT OF QUIET ENJOYMENT (M.G.L. c. 186, § 14)

G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 3.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 3, and G.L. c. 218, § 19, as the amount in controversy does not exceed the jurisdictional limits of the District Court.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 3, and G.L. c. 218, § 19, as the amount in controversy does not exceed the jurisdictional limits of the District Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court under G.L. c. 223, § 2, because the property that is the subject of this complaint is located in Lowell, Massachusetts, within the jurisdiction of the Lowell District Court.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Defendant’s conduct violates G.L. c. 186, § 14, which prohibits a landlord from directly or indirectly interfering with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the leased premises.

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7\u00a7 127A\u2013127L.proposition: Defendant’s actions also violate G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L, and the State Sanitary Code (105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq.), which require that dwellings be maintained free from chronic dampness and mold growth.

State Sanitary Code (105 C.M.R. 410.000.raw_text: State Sanitary Code (105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq.)
State Sanitary Code (105 C.M.R. 410.000.proposition: Defendant’s actions also violate G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L, and the State Sanitary Code (105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq.), which require that dwellings be maintained free from chronic dampness and mold growth.

G.L. c. 239, \u00a7 8A.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is further protected by G.L. c. 239, § 8A, which affords tenants a defense and counterclaim for violations of G.L. c. 186, § 14, the State Sanitary Code, or related laws.

Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 3.raw_text: Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 3.proposition: Defendant’s conduct constitutes a breach of her statutory and common-law duties under Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973); Hemingway v. Tufts, 361 Mass. 183 (1972); Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997); and Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).
Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 3.support_reasoning: The proposition asserts that the defendant’s conduct constitutes a breach of her statutory and common-law duties under Hemingway. This excerpt is a concurring/dissenting opinion focused on landlord duties and the implied warranty/habitability framework, not tenant duties. It does not articulate or apply any statutory or common-law duties owed by a tenant, nor does it characterize tenant conduct as breaching such duties. Thus, this opinion does not support the specific proposition about a defendant-tenant’s breach of her duties.
Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 3.relevant_excerpt: “The situation before us is that tenants who have admittedly withheld payment of rent for apartments which they continued to occupy despite alleged violations of the Code now take the position that by reason of the violations the landlord may neither evict them nor recover any rent from them. The opinion of the court holds that the tenants are subject to eviction because of their failure to pay rent, but that their liability for unpaid rent is limited to the reasonable value, if any, of their apartments, considering the alleged violations of the Code.”

Hemingway v. Tufts, 361 Mass. 183 (1972).proposition: Defendant’s conduct constitutes a breach of her statutory and common-law duties under Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973); Hemingway v. Tufts, 361 Mass. 183 (1972); Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997); and Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).
Hemingway v. Tufts, 361 Mass. 183 (1972).case_name: Boston Safe Deposit & Trust Co. v. Fleming
Hemingway v. Tufts, 361 Mass. 183 (1972).support_reasoning: This opinion is Boston Safe Deposit & Trust Co. v. Fleming, 361 Mass. 172 (1972), a trust/estates case about whether adopted grandchildren qualify as “issue” under a will. It does not involve landlord-tenant law, habitability, or statutory/common-law duties related to housing conditions at all, and in fact is not Hemingway v. Tufts. Therefore it does not support the proposition that a defendant’s conduct breaches duties under Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway or related housing cases.
Hemingway v. Tufts, 361 Mass. 183 (1972).relevant_excerpt: “In the present situation, the question for decision is whether under c. 210, § 8, as it read prior to the 1958 amendment, the two Flemings adopted in California, can be included within the term ‘issue’ as used by the testator in his will, interpreted and construed in accordance with Massachusetts law.”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).proposition: Defendant’s conduct constitutes a breach of her statutory and common-law duties under Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973); Hemingway v. Tufts, 361 Mass. 183 (1972); Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997); and Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).support_reasoning: This opinion narrows, rather than expands, landlord liability under the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment. It holds that a mere statutory violation (here, strict-liability lead paint violations) does not, without proof of at least negligent conduct and notice, constitute a breach of G.L. c. 186, § 14. Thus, Al‑Ziab does not stand for the broad proposition that the defendant’s conduct (here, simply violating the lead paint statute) is itself a breach of statutory and common‑law duties under Hemingway and related cases; instead it emphasizes the need to prove landlord fault for quiet enjoyment claims.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).relevant_excerpt: “Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord and violation of the lead paint statute alone is not sufficient to prove such negligence. Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Under Simon v. Solomon, supra, and Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977), substantial interference with the tenant’s enjoyment of the premises, attributable to the landlord’s acts or omissions, constitutes a breach of quiet enjoyment even in the absence of malice or direct physical eviction.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The court squarely addresses the standard for breach of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14 and under the common-law covenant. It expressly rejects a requirement of malicious or specific intent, explaining that liability turns on the landlord’s conduct where substantial interference with the tenant’s tenancy is the natural and probable consequence, and it cites Blackett v. Olanoff for the principle that the landlord’s conduct, not intent, controls. The decision thus supports the proposition that substantial interference attributable to the landlord’s acts or omissions can constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment without malice or direct physical eviction.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … Although early cases applying the covenant of quiet enjoyment required intent on the part of the landlord… more recent decisions have imposed liability whenever the ‘natural and probable consequence’ of a landlord’s action was interruption of the tenant’s rights. … In Blackett v. Olanoff… we held that ‘the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions’ determine whether he has violated the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: Under Simon v. Solomon, supra, and Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977), substantial interference with the tenant’s enjoyment of the premises, attributable to the landlord’s acts or omissions, constitutes a breach of quiet enjoyment even in the absence of malice or direct physical eviction.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that a landlord breaches the covenant of quiet enjoyment and constructively evicts tenants where substantial interference with their use (here, extreme bar noise) is the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did or failed to do, even though the landlords did not intend to deprive the tenants of possession. The court explicitly disclaims an intent or malice requirement and focuses on the landlord’s conduct and control over the interfering conditions, which matches the proposition’s description of substantial interference attributable to the landlord’s acts or omissions sufficing for breach without malice or physical eviction.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Although some of our opinions have spoken of particular action or inaction by a landlord as showing a presumed intention to evict, the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.”

Jerome v. Commonwealth, 25 Mass. App. Ct.raw_text: Jerome v. Commonwealth, 25 Mass. App. Ct. 933 (1987)
Jerome v. Commonwealth, 25 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Defendant’s failure to address mold and unfit living conditions constitutes an indirect act of interference comparable to the constructive eviction recognized in Jerome v. Commonwealth, 25 Mass. App. Ct. 933 (1987).
Jerome v. Commonwealth, 25 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: Jerome v. Commonwealth is a criminal case about suppression of evidence, police pursuit, reasonable suspicion, and sufficiency of evidence for armed robbery and related offenses. It does not address landlord-tenant law, habitability, mold, unfit living conditions, or constructive eviction. Using this case as authority for the proposition that a landlord’s failure to address mold/unfit conditions is an indirect interference comparable to constructive eviction is therefore inaccurate and unsupported by the opinion.
Jerome v. Commonwealth, 25 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: Canty’s actions in following the car for a very short distance amounted to surveillance, not “pursuit.” … Thus, whatever the state of the officers’ knowledge at the time about the defendants’ involvement in the crime prior to their speeding away, neither their Fourth Amendment nor their State constitutional rights were violated. … Finally, Raphael Groves contends that there was insufficient evidence to implicate him in the unlawful carrying of the gun.

Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162 (1980).proposition: The continuing failure to maintain the premises in a habitable condition also violates Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162 (1980), which holds landlords responsible for conditions that pose unreasonable risks to tenants.
Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162 (1980).support_reasoning: Young v. Garwacki expressly abandons the old caveat lessee rule and holds that landlords, like other persons, must exercise reasonable care not to subject others to unreasonable risks of harm from conditions on the rented premises, including areas within the tenant’s exclusive control. While the case is framed in negligence rather than the modern “habitability” terminology, its core holding is that landlords are responsible in tort for unsafe conditions that pose unreasonable risks to tenants and their guests. Thus it provides strong authority for the stated proposition about landlord responsibility for dangerous conditions on the premises.
Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162 (1980).relevant_excerpt: “Henceforth, landlords as other persons must exercise reasonable care not to subject others to an unreasonable risk of harm. A landlord must act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk. … Henceforth, this basic principle of responsibility applies to Massachusetts landlords as well.” (380 Mass. at 169).
